WRITING.TEXT: Sometimes I'm just anxious all night. And that's ok.

Only time will tell. Everyone reacts differently. A doctor can prescribe medication to ease the dangerous symptoms if they appear.
Good luck.

I developed a firm and solid foundation for sobriety and let it live a life of its own.
I did this through attending inpatient and outpatient treatment and doing a lot of writing on how me and alcohol were not compatible.

My husband feels like doing weird things sometimes too.
I just listen and then ask what he needs.
Is he going through anything right now?
It's been such a trip! One month is huge! I remember getting my one month chip in rehab and feeling on top of the world :)

My one year medallion and my five year coin gifted to me by a friend on this subreddit are two things I truly, truly treasure. And you're right, they totally represent more than just "I stopped drinking." They are a testament to my vigilance and hard work!

I won't drink anything that tastes like something that almost killed me. I just don't want to remember those tastes, those feelings, that sickening feeling of "uh oh, I started this, better finish it."
I find that no one really cares what I am drinking. So I drink what I like when I go to bars: Shirley Temples.
That being said, non-alcoholic beer has some alcohol in it. It would be breaking my sobriety to consciously choose to consume anything with alcohol in it.
I used to drink listerine so I can relate to this. When I wanted a buzz, I was gonna fucking get it.

I remember being that woman. That video broke my heart a little.
I am so glad to be where I am today. Going to go hug my bunny.
We sure are trending.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules of those subreddit. Telling someone they will always be addicted is not how we give support and encouragement.
This comment has been removed.

I still have a healthy dose of fear. I channel it and use it. I don't let it consume or paralyze me. Fear is very motivating for me. I counter fear with fun, humour and huge sense of curiosity. I realized that when I got sober, the whole world was available to me. Terrifying. But so fucking exciting!

But I never thought about drinking.
What a wonderful place to be. When first thoughts are not "I need to get fucking hammered"
Sorry about the job man.

Ok I was wrong then!
I don't go to AA anymore, but I did.
I maintain a dry house, unless we have friends coming over, then I don't mind. I had booze at my wedding when I was 2.5 years sober. I go to bars for dinner. I go to parties. I work around alcohol.
I say I am in recovery from substance abuse. I don't call myself an alcoholic anymore. I used to. I prefer to label myself as "in recovery" because that's a more accurate representation than saying I have a drinking problem and using a term that is outdated.
I do avoid trace amounts of alcohol. This is purely because of habit, I've been doing it since day 1 and don't really see any point of adding small quantities of alcohol back into my life. It doesn't make sense. The purported health benefits of kombucha are outweighed by the fact that there is alcohol in there.
I do not feel at risk of relapse. That sounds cocky. But I am sure of my beliefs, goals, and dreams in life. I check in with myself everyday, I maintain open and honest lines of communication with my husband, family and friends and I do work that helps me stay humble.
I don't go to AA anymore. I would be cautious to paint every single AA member with a broad brush.
Hey anytime. I hope you check in Wednesday and let us know how it goes. Everything will turn out okay. You're okay.

Moderation and alcohol don't go together in my life. I don't want to moderate my alcohol consumption. I also don't think I am capable of it: it's something I am not willing to test out. My sober life outweighs getting high.
Please only post when sober my friend.

Oh those little purchases: still dealing with that. It starts adding up eh? Damn we're all so similar sometimes.
Glad you're feeling calmer. Sounds like you get really panicky when things aren't in your control. I can relate to that. Over the years I've developed some resiliency, but it's still hard.
I dated someone who was in and out of his recovery. It was really hard. I ended up becoming really obsessive about his safety and in the end, we both parted ways.

I'm still learning to deal with money. Something I do that helps me from impulse buying is to kind of check in with how I am feeling mentally before I go out. Like, if I am grumpy or cranky, and I do shopping, I'm at more of a risk to buy shit I don't need. Sometimes just saying "I am cranky and I think this shit will change how I feel" stops the impulse to buy.
Other times I need to actually give myself barriers. Not bringing my debit card, or bringing a certain amount of money.
It's easier said than done. I think what has helped me the most is saving for big things. Right now, I am all about saving 100 dollars a month so that I can secretly buy my husband a Lazy-Boy chair.
So really, I mentally check in and name the feeling. Then I'll physically limit access, and the biggest thing is having larger plans and making a very simple process for getting there.
Sorry that was so long haha

Money is like a drug for me. In early recovery I had such a hard time dealing with it and thinking about it. It was never enough, but when I had it, I just wanted to treat myself.
I hope you are able to recruit your brother. Are you two close?

Is there anyone you'd be willing to contact to help you stay safe Wednesday night? I know that if it's an AA meeting, someone will go with you if you call intergroup.
You're in my thoughts man, money is such a trigger for me.
I'm sorry you're feeling that way. Is it a thought right now, or do you have a plan?
Hi Bobo, are you considering suicide? No judgment.
Welcome. I didn't think I had a problem with alcohol until I checked into rehab. So in my experience, recovery happened before I made a hard and fast decision to stay sober.

Oh my god. I am so sorry. There is nothing wrong with starting school and making decisions. A sponsor is supposed to take you through the steps, not give you life advice and tell you you're a dry drunk.
I will relapse if I stop being true to myself and my word. I will relapse if I start doing what everyone thinks I should and stop engaging in the life I envision for my self.
It sounds like she wasn't willing to sponsor someone who didn't take her word as god.
Sweet! The benefits of not keeping booze around in my opinion.
You're awesome!
Welcome man. Homeless shelters are difficult places to get and stay sober. I hope your new place is a safe haven for you!
Yeeeep that's their job.

I was told that hanging out around alcohol and not drinking in early recovery would cause my brain to start second guessing my sobriety. This is why I stuck very firmly to dry people and dry places until I was almost 5 months sober.
That is reprehensible behaviour. I hope she gets some help, or perspective, or something.
We cannot tell you if you will experience DT's. Hospital is never a bad idea.
My body needed a lot of rest, hydration and time before I started to feel better.

After two years sober, I decided that I would allow alcohol in my house under special circumstances. I also had alcohol flowing freely at my wedding. My belief is to not push my lifestyle and health choices on others. I go with the flow.

What if I am fun, and the party goes well?
These days I am just going for it. I have planned a few parties since I got sober, and they've been fun. I think it's all about just having confidence and setting the tone.
That being said, are you planning to break sobriety over this party?
Welcome!

I can drink again.
I choose not to. Because what happens to me when I drink.
I also have fun at bars now. More fun than I did when I was constantly making an ass out of myself and sneaking vodka in the bathroom.

I didn't want to quit. But I didn't want to die. I was at a weird crossroads. I decided to give sobriety a try, because I could always go back out to drinking if I wanted.
I decided to go all in. I became open, honest and willing.
I guess I sort of tricked myself into quitting. A very small part of me wanted it. I got a lot of support, did a lot of hard work, soul searching and a lot of practical things...and that small part became bigger and bigger. Now I cannot imagine my life as a drinker. It doesn't fit with who I am as a person.

I need to remember that other people's sobriety is not my responsibility. As someone with a few years sober, I don't have all the answers for others. I don't take people under my wing or anything like that. I treat people as equals and peers.
In the sidebar there are lots of out stories. They are called Saturday Shares :)

If something is bothering me, I either need to let it go or change it. There are lots of ways to reduce your level of smoking.
For me, I choose decaf over regular. I've weened down from over 600mg a day to under 100mg. I feel great.
I wouldn't. She is free to make her decisions. I doubt she would appreciate being followed around. What's your motive?
I find it hard to eat at fancy beer restaurants. Whyyyy do they need to infuse everything with alcohol, whyyyy!

I wish I could say it was easy.
I cried, kicked, screamed and was confused. I went to meetings for the next few days religiously and ate a lot of Chinese food and ice cream.

I was very similar.
For me, I realized that I had spent my teenage and early 20's focused on myself.
I decided that life was meaningless because I was making it that way. So I changed my perspective. I wanted to care about something. So I searched. And I found it.
What have you tried?

Anticipating drinking is just as intoxicating as drinking. It's crazy brain neurochemistry. Like an adrenaline rush for the mind.
I hope you find some relief soon. Everything changes. Cravings pass.

How exciting and terrifying, a whole new plethora of activities to do!
:)
All sorts of new things for you this year! Welcome and congrats. One week is HUGE

I took up
- going to meetings
- drinking more coffee
- going for runs and going to the gym
- reading recovery literature
- meditation
But I mean, whatever works.
The thing is, I can become obsessive about anything that is rewarding. I've got passionate and obsessive tendencies. And it obviously got me into trouble.
For me, quitting drinking was a jumping off point for changing the way I interacted with the world. Instead of changing one thing for another, I started going, "Wait, how is this serving me? What do I value and believe in? What can I channel this addictive tendency towards that is healthy and helpful?"

That's very nice of you! I remember that post as well.
The thing is: many people post or comment once or twice and never return. I wonder where they go. I wish them well!

I'm sorry you aren't getting the support you're looking for from your friends. For me, I needed to surround myself with non-drinkers for the first year or so. Changing my lifestyle was easier when people around me had the same one.
That's probably part of the reason why your friends aren't being overly supportive: they are in their drinking lifestyle. Someone splitting from that, so abruptly, is shocking. They may need some time to adjust.

I still have dreams about demolishing a pizza or cake once in a while too
Oh my :(

Running in the snow is hard. Looking at every step, figuring out the path infront of you, paying attention to stride and having to actually move with purpose...
I find it therapeutic. And super frustrating...so I am forced to practice my patience!
I had them quite often in my first 1.5 years!
Please speak from your experience.

We are not doctors and cannot answer medical questions.
All I know is that if you're really concerned, the ER or a walk in clinic could give you some peace of mind.

Like any others social media platform, I feel like we tend to share the good. Many of our lives seem rosier than they really are.
I welcome your honesty.
Wow this sounds like a huge win!!

Civ 6, SD and ice cream.
Life's good!

There is nothing wrong with wanting balance in life. I remember feeling guilty for choosing to go to the gym rather than another meeting. For me sobriety means balance. That didn't include daily AA meetings. I wanted to experience life in all ways.

Welcome. At some point I realized I was repeating patterns of addictive behaviour with different substances and behaviours. I decided it was time to find a way to live that prevented me from becoming overly attached and committed to everything I touched.
I hope you find what you need here. AA isn't reserved for people without insight. It's for anyone who wants to stop drinking.
Your friends care about you. It's pretty annoying sometimes. I remember wishing people would leave me alone in my misery.
Please review the community guidelines and speak from the I. We do not give direct advice here.

It's nice to have opinions and judgments about others, but they have to live with themselves at the end of the day. We just get to observe them. That's why I respect people's right to make their own choices.
Please only post when sober.

I just wonder about the state that someone is left in when approached about their problem.
OP mentioned living in a different country and seeing them randomly, and it seems like times where people might imbibe more. Holidays, get togethers with old friends.
As well, I feel like it's irresponsible to plant a seed "Hey man I'm concerned that every time I see you, you're talking about drinking" and then just leave. I feel like if you are going to try to burst someone's bubble, you need to at least be available or have resources for them to continue their journey. Not just a "I think you have a problem, see you next Christmas"

Gotta be honest. Getting to one year was okay, but it's more the quality of life I have. The time accumulated isn't much of a reward anymore.
Expecting to feel accomplished when I do something sets me up for being disappointed. I like to focus on living better today, and setting myself up for success.

I wouldn't say anything. Someone's drinking problem isn't my problem. It's nice to want to help people, but I've rarely seen things go well when friends try to intervene on each other. It's usually a mess.
I bet your intentions are in the right place, but this is his personal business.

Welcome! Those first few weekends for me were like the twilight zone. What the fuck do people do without drinking, and then nursing a hangover?
I found a whole new world out there.

Some people like repetition. Others don't. There are other options out there if you'd like to stop. I used inpatient rehab as my starter, then branched out into outpatient group therapy that was run by professionals. They always made sure the topic was new, and the group dynamic got really close. It was an amazing experience.
Fucking Christmas candy. WHYYY

That sounds difficult. I know that for me feeling connected with people has been the most important thing in recovery. I felt so alone, different and alienated when I was drinking.
When I got into recovery, I made a conscious effort to hang out with other sober people. Sooner or later, I started feeling like part of the regular human race again...I stopped seeing us as "alcoholics vs. normies" and started realizing that we all had our shit. Being in recovery from substance abuse doesn't make me abnormal. We're all recovering from something.

It's funny because what's "worse" for me may not be "worse" for you.
It's all relative, depending on what I value in life.

I think I have carried around my baggage, trauma, pain and anger because it makes me feel entitled to act and behave in certain ways.
I am in love with the quote by Najwa Zebian: "These mountains that you are carrying, you were only supposed to climb"
I carry around things, events, moments, hates, loves, likes...when maybe, If I let it go...who knows what would happen.
For me there is a difference between letting things go after I have worked through them, and avoidance. For example, some trauma I've been through...I don't go "It doesn't affect me anymore"...that's not fair. It might. Instead, I don't carry around the story anymore and let it define my life. Same with substance abuse.
YES! I realized I hated people who were in recovery from substance abuse because I fucking hated myself and refused to believe I was one of "them"
There are thousands of posts on SD about first days. Many people read this sub for hours getting tips.
I don't know anything about it.
Yep. I am in recovery from an eating disorder, anxiety disorder and alcohol dependence! Woo hoo!
The numbers I've crunched over the past 5 years don't fit with the numbers they found. But that's none of my business :)
Can't control people :)
Nothing shocking yet! I will update in 24 hours with some cool data.
Is this sarcasm?
I am totally glad too! I guess sometimes I just feel a little weird that people are doing research on us without our explicit consent.

WRITING.TITLE: We grow again
WRITING.TEXT:
The Daily Mail has just written a blurb on SD. Usually they ask the mods for permission, but not this time!
I guess Recovery.org has done a bunch of research on us...without our consent or knowledge (I know, reddit is open to everyone).
I'm both saddened and enlivened by SD press!
[Check it out](http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-4093086/Research-finds-Reddit-helping-40-000-recovering-alcoholics-sobriety.html)
Wow! We had no idea!

Cravings for me are emotion riddled thoughts propelled by years and years of reinforcement and conditioning.
Aka - cravings seemed intensely important to me. But I stopped reacting to them and it gave them less power.
Congratulations!!
I love when people tell me what is and is not wrong with me, based on limited information, a ton of biases and without any prompting.
I'm so sorry.
That's too bad. What's your new plan?

Speaking from the I means speaking from experience. We don't give direct advice on SD. It comes from a peer support model of recovery. I don't know you. You knoq you. Me telling you what to do and how to think isnt what we do on sd. So we tell our story, share what worked for us.
Instead of saying "you need to look at it like this" (which is an attempt to set someone straight), we say "I look at it like this"
The challenging part just isn't supporting. It's directly telling someone "this is what I believe you need"
Hope that clarifies. Yes we take this place very seriously. I know it sounds intense, but we've grown a lot because of the way we approach one another.
Please speak from the I and do not challenge people. It's not supportive or encouraging.
I was very similar. I needed serious help. It started with a trip to my doctor.
I was going to die. I wanted to die. That scared me.

There are a whackload of people celebrating one year today who joined us. Hell, /u/ninjilla is sending out one year coins to all these people as well!
Welcome to SD. I hope you find what you need here.
You too dear!
Haha I almost tagged this with our Hoser flair, but didn't want to scare away the Canucks!
Shit yes you will
Days 1-4 were fucking hell!
Hey we just came back from a walk as well! What a beautiful way to start a new year eh?

I fell out of favour with the ideas and beliefs that were behind the AA program. I also felt like it was very cliquey. I tried to go to different meetings and got involved in service, but it stopped feeling right.
I was also confused. I was told that if I stopped going to AA meetings, I'd relapse. That sounded irrational to me. Like, why would I need to continue to go to meetings for the rest of my life? Could I find something else that worked for me, that kept me aware of my problem, but didn't require me to somehow KEEP identifying as an alcoholic day after day?
I was also realizing that people on SD had never gone to AA and had stayed sober. Then I started to learn and read about substance abuse, and the theories behind it...and I realized there was more to do than a simple disease model.
So, it was a lot of things that accumulated over time.
Now I work in the substance abuse field, I volunteer with substance abuse organizations, I got training in peer support, and use SD as my support. I am happy and feel more well rounded than I did when I was in AA.
Happy One Year my friend!

WRITING.TITLE: A Huge Welcome
WRITING.TEXT:
New Years.
For many of us, New Years brings a fresh slate, a clean start to a whole new year. It provides motivation to start new behaviours and end old ones that may not be serving us anymore.
On SD, we are here to support and encourage each other in our attempts and successes to cut down or quit drinking.
Regardless of your goal, where you are, or how ambivalent you are...you are welcome here.
The [FAQ and guidelines](https://www.reddit.com/r/stopdrinking/wiki/index) are a fantastic place to start. It includes commonly asked questions such as
- Why aren't people giving me direct advice?
- What's with speaking from your experience? Isn't it easier to just tell people how it is?
- Why aren't people giving me tips on how to cut down my drinking?
- Why are there so many non-drinkers here, where are the moderate ones?
- What are badges, what are those stars and numbers? What do they mean?
There are hundreds of resources out there. As part of my New Year Resolution plan, I actually follow SAMHSA's 8 Dimensions of Wellness, and have written down and mapped out a solid plan for me. [Here is what I use, pages 8-19](http://www.integration.samhsa.gov/health-wellness/wellness-strategies/wellness.pdf)
There is also
- AA
- SMART recovery
- Refuge Recovery
- Inpatient and outpatient treatment
- Finding a substance abuse counsellor
- Using exercise, nutrition or meditation
- Any combination and anything that works for you
Happy New Year and WELCOME!!!!
I don't use AA anymore. I did though.
Welcome hi!
I wouldn't have wanted someone to do this to me when drunk...its not very nice.

I was told that 95% of people relapsed within a year after leaving the rehab I went to.
I did everything in my fucking power to get better and beat those odds. And I did. So fuck you statistics. I have choice and power over what I put into my body and how I react to stress.
I am responsible for my sobriety. I am responsible if I start drinking again. I am under no obligation to drink if someone offers me a beer or tries to get me to start drinking. My body, my choice.
Please do not post when you've been drinking.

"THEM THIGHS"
Yes, yes they are marvelous.
You're amazing thank you!
